intro: Lapsana pusilla, commonly known as common lesser mouse-ear, is a small annual herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters, featuring hairy, lance-shaped leaves and small, yellowish flowers arranged in a cluster. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and can be found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. It is characterized by its distinctive basal rosette of leaves and its ability to produce numerous seeds that are dispersed by wind. Lapsana pusilla is often considered a weed but has historical uses in traditional medicine.
